articles.headline: Why Louisiana’s Electric Grid Failed in Hurricane Ida
articles.snippet: Much of the state, including New Orleans, lost power for days because many of Entergy’s electrical poles and towers were not built to withstand a major hurricane, energy experts said.
articles.abstract: Much of the state, including New Orleans, lost power for days because many of Entergy’s electrical poles and towers were not built to withstand a major hurricane, energy experts said.
articles.lead_paragraph: Just weeks before Hurricane Ida knocked out power to much of Louisiana, leaving its residents exposed to extreme heat and humidity, the chief executive of Entergy, the state’s biggest utility company, told Wall Street that it had been upgrading power lines and equipment to withstand big storms.
articles.byline: By Peter Eavis and Ivan Penn

articles.headline: Why Washington Worries About Stablecoins
articles.snippet: The Federal Reserve, Treasury and other regulators are worried that a technology that pledges stability will actually be a source of turmoil.
articles.abstract: The Federal Reserve, Treasury and other regulators are worried that a technology that pledges stability will actually be a source of turmoil.
articles.lead_paragraph: Stablecoins might be the most ironically named innovation of the cryptocurrency era, at least in the eyes of many Washington regulators and policymakers.
articles.byline: By Jeanna Smialek

articles.headline: Pentagon acknowledges Aug. 29 drone strike in Afghanistan was a tragic mistake that killed 10 civilians.
articles.snippet: The findings of the inquiry mirrored a New York Times investigation of video evidence, along with interviews with more than a dozen of the driver’s co-workers and family members in Kabul.
articles.abstract: The findings of the inquiry mirrored a New York Times investigation of video evidence, along with interviews with more than a dozen of the driver’s co-workers and family members in Kabul.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Pentagon acknowledged on Friday that the last U.S. drone strike before American troops withdrew from Afghanistan was a tragic mistake that killed 10 civilians, including seven children, after initially saying it had been necessary to prevent an attack on troops.
articles.byline: By Eric Schmitt and Helene Cooper

articles.headline: Tim Cook Faces Surprising Employee Unrest at Apple
articles.snippet: Hundreds of current and former Apple workers are complaining about their work environment, a rarity for the once tight-lipped company.
articles.abstract: Hundreds of current and former Apple workers are complaining about their work environment, a rarity for the once tight-lipped company.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Apple, known among its Silicon Valley peers for a secretive corporate culture in which workers are expected to be in lock step with management, is suddenly facing an issue that would have been unthinkable a few years ago: employee unrest.
articles.byline: By Jack Nicas and Kellen Browning

articles.headline: F.D.A. Advisory Panel Recommends Pfizer Boosters for Older People and Others at High Risk
articles.snippet: The committee said there was insufficient evidence to recommend third shots for all adult recipients of the vaccine, as Pfizer had requested.
articles.abstract: The committee said there was insufficient evidence to recommend third shots for all adult recipients of the vaccine, as Pfizer had requested.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A key advisory panel to the Food and Drug Administration overwhelmingly rejected recommending Pfizer booster shots for most recipients of the company’s coronavirus vaccine, instead endorsing them only for people who are 65 or older or at high risk of severe Covid-19, and received their second dose at least six months ago.
articles.byline: By Sharon LaFraniere and Noah Weiland

articles.headline: Robert Durst Found Guilty of Murder After Decades of Suspicion
articles.snippet: Mr. Durst, the onetime heir to a Manhattan real estate empire, was convicted of killing a close confidante in Beverly Hills, Calif., in 2000.
articles.abstract: Mr. Durst, the onetime heir to a Manhattan real estate empire, was convicted of killing a close confidante in Beverly Hills, Calif., in 2000.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Robert A. Durst, the enigmatic real estate scion who evaded criminal suspicion for half his life only to become a national sensation after damaging admissions were aired in a 2015 documentary on HBO, was convicted on Friday in the execution-style murder of a close confidante more than 20 years ago.
articles.byline: By Charles V. Bagli

articles.headline: Secret Talks and a Hidden Agenda: Behind the U.S. Defense Deal That France Called a ‘Betrayal’
articles.snippet: In meeting after meeting with their French counterparts, U.S. officials gave no heads-up about their plans to upend France’s largest defense contract.
articles.abstract: In meeting after meeting with their French counterparts, U.S. officials gave no heads-up about their plans to upend France’s largest defense contract.
articles.lead_paragraph: The United States and Australia went to extraordinary lengths to keep Paris in the dark as they secretly negotiated a plan to build nuclear submarines, scuttling France’s largest defense contract and so enraging President Emmanuel Macron that on Friday he ordered the withdrawal of France’s ambassadors to both nations.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger

articles.headline: The Scientist and the A.I.-Assisted, Remote-Control Killing Machine
articles.snippet: Israeli agents had wanted to kill Iran’s top nuclear scientist for years. Then they came up with a way to do it with no operatives present.
articles.abstract: Israeli agents had wanted to kill Iran’s top nuclear scientist for years. Then they came up with a way to do it with no operatives present.
articles.lead_paragraph: Iran’s top nuclear scientist woke up an hour before dawn, as he did most days, to study Islamic philosophy before his day began.
articles.byline: By Ronen Bergman and Farnaz Fassihi

articles.headline: Biden’s Entire Presidential Agenda Rests on Expansive Spending Bill
articles.snippet: A plan for the economy, education, immigration, climate and more binds disparate Democratic lawmakers, but the proposal risks sinking under its own weight.
articles.abstract: A plan for the economy, education, immigration, climate and more binds disparate Democratic lawmakers, but the proposal risks sinking under its own weight.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — No president has ever packed as much of his agenda, domestic and foreign, into a single piece of legislation as President Biden has with the $3.5 trillion spending plan that Democrats are trying to wrangle through Congress over the next six weeks.
articles.byline: By Jim Tankersley

articles.headline: Submarine Deal Gives Post-Brexit Britain Its Moment on the Global Stage
articles.snippet: The British government played an early role in brokering the alliance with the U.S. and Australia to deploy nuclear-powered submarines in the Pacific, officials in London and Washington said.
articles.abstract: The British government played an early role in brokering the alliance with the U.S. and Australia to deploy nuclear-powered submarines in the Pacific, officials in London and Washington said.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — As relations between France and the United States sink to their lowest depths in decades, Britain has emerged as the unlikely winner in a maritime security alliance that has sowed anger and recrimination across three continents.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler

articles.headline: Evergrande Gave Workers a Choice: Lend Us Cash or Lose Your Bonus
articles.snippet: The Chinese property giant owes $300 billion and is on the hook for as many as 1.6 million apartments. It may owe tens of thousands of its employees money, too.
articles.abstract: The Chinese property giant owes $300 billion and is on the hook for as many as 1.6 million apartments. It may owe tens of thousands of its employees money, too.
articles.lead_paragraph: When the troubled Chinese property giant Evergrande was starved for cash earlier this year, it turned to its own employees with a strong-arm pitch: Those who wanted to keep their bonuses would have to give Evergrande a short-term loan.
articles.byline: By Alexandra Stevenson and Cao Li

articles.headline: Life After Proclaiming a Trump Re-election as Divinely Ordained
articles.snippet: When you are in the business of prophecy, what do you do when prophecy fails?
articles.abstract: When you are in the business of prophecy, what do you do when prophecy fails?
articles.lead_paragraph: This spring, the media mogul Stephen E. Strang made an unusual apology to readers in the pages of his glossy magazine.
articles.byline: By Sam Kestenbaum

articles.headline: In the Heart of Nashville, Rolling Parties Rage at Every Stoplight
articles.snippet: As Nashville’s popularity has grown, so has the “transportainment” business — a motley assortment including old buses, farm tractors and a truck with a hot tub. Many think it has gotten out of hand.
articles.abstract: As Nashville’s popularity has grown, so has the “transportainment” business — a motley assortment including old buses, farm tractors and a truck with a hot tub. Many think it has gotten out of hand.
articles.lead_paragraph: NASHVILLE — The John Deere tractor pulled onto Broadway and rumbled into the madness.
articles.byline: By Rick Rojas and William DeShazer

articles.headline: How Accounting Giants Craft Favorable Tax Rules From Inside Government
articles.snippet: Lawyers from top accounting firms do brief stints in the Treasury Department, with the expectation of big raises when they return.
articles.abstract: Lawyers from top accounting firms do brief stints in the Treasury Department, with the expectation of big raises when they return.
articles.lead_paragraph: For six years, Audrey Ellis and Adam Feuerstein worked together at PwC, the giant accounting firm, helping the world’s biggest companies avoid taxes.
articles.byline: By Jesse Drucker and Danny Hakim

articles.headline: With Abortion Rights Under Threat, Democrats Hope to Go on Offense
articles.snippet: Warning of Texas-style laws nationwide, the party believes it can use the issue to turn out suburban women in the Virginia governor’s race this fall and the 2022 midterms.
articles.abstract: Warning of Texas-style laws nationwide, the party believes it can use the issue to turn out suburban women in the Virginia governor’s race this fall and the 2022 midterms.
articles.lead_paragraph: VIRGINIA BEACH — Kenzie Smith is “not big into politics,” she said, and while she votes faithfully in presidential elections, for Democrats, she is less interested in off-year races, such as those seven weeks away in Virginia for governor and the legislature.
articles.byline: By Trip Gabriel

articles.headline: Haiti Protests Mass U.S. Deportation of Migrants to Country in Crisis
articles.snippet: Haiti migration officials have asked the United States for a “humanitarian moratorium” even as they receive the first returnees from Texas. “Will we have enough to feed these people?”
articles.abstract: Haiti migration officials have asked the United States for a “humanitarian moratorium” even as they receive the first returnees from Texas. “Will we have enough to feed these people?”
articles.lead_paragraph: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti — The first Haitians deported from a makeshift camp in Texas landed in their home country Sunday amid sweltering heat, anger and confusion, as Haitian officials beseeched the United States to stop the flights because the country is in crisis and cannot handle thousands of homeless deportees.
articles.byline: By Harold Isaac and Catherine Porter

articles.headline: Merkel’s Children: Living Legacies Called Angela, Angie and Sometimes Merkel
articles.snippet: For some refugee families who traveled to Germany during the migrant crisis of 2015 and 2016, gratitude for Chancellor Angela Merkel’s decision to welcome them comes via a namesake.
articles.abstract: For some refugee families who traveled to Germany during the migrant crisis of 2015 and 2016, gratitude for Chancellor Angela Merkel’s decision to welcome them comes via a namesake.
articles.lead_paragraph: WÜLFRATH, Germany — Hibaja Maai gave birth three days after arriving in Germany.
articles.byline: By Katrin Bennhold

articles.headline: How the U.S. Helped, and Hampered, the Escape of Afghan Journalists
articles.snippet: The secretary of state cites a “massive effort” by the government, but people involved in the evacuation instead describe bureaucratic snags.
articles.abstract: The secretary of state cites a “massive effort” by the government, but people involved in the evacuation instead describe bureaucratic snags.
articles.lead_paragraph: As American news organizations scrambled to evacuate their Afghan journalists and their families last month, I reported that those working for The New York Times had found refuge not in New York or Washington, but in Mexico City.
articles.byline: By Ben Smith

articles.headline: Medicare Expansion Clashes With Health Care for the Poor as Budget Bill Shrinks
articles.snippet: Under pressure to cut the bill’s cost, Democrats disagree over whether to offer more benefits to older Americans or to cover more of the working poor.
articles.abstract: Under pressure to cut the bill’s cost, Democrats disagree over whether to offer more benefits to older Americans or to cover more of the working poor.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Democrats are facing tough moral and political decisions over how to pursue their century-old dream of universal health care now that their ambitious $3.5 trillion social safety net bill will almost certainly have to be trimmed back.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Weisman and Sheryl Gay Stolberg

articles.headline: Global Supply Shortages Reach All the Way to a Haitian Aid Group
articles.snippet: Continuing disruption to factory production and bottlenecks in shipping are leaving nonprofit groups short of goods for vulnerable communities worldwide.
articles.abstract: Continuing disruption to factory production and bottlenecks in shipping are leaving nonprofit groups short of goods for vulnerable communities worldwide.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the face of bewildering and enduring shortages of goods throughout the global economy, even aid organizations like food banks and clothing distributors are caught in the chaos. Many are struggling to secure what they need, amplifying scarcity in vulnerable communities.
articles.byline: By Peter S. Goodman

articles.headline: Global Markets Swoon as Worries Mount Over Superpowers’ Plans
articles.snippet: The S&P 500 closed down 1.7 percent over a number of jitters, like China’s sputtering real estate market and the phasing out of stimulus measures in the United States.
articles.abstract: The S&P 500 closed down 1.7 percent over a number of jitters, like China’s sputtering real estate market and the phasing out of stimulus measures in the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: Investors on three continents dumped stocks on Monday, fretting that the governments of the world’s two largest economies — China and the United States — would act in ways that could undercut the nascent global economic recovery.
articles.byline: By Matt Phillips, Eshe Nelson and Coral Murphy Marcos

articles.headline: A Harsh New Reality for Afghan Women and Girls in Taliban-Run Schools
articles.snippet: Afghanistan’s new government is likely to severely restrict education for girls and women despite the Taliban’s claims that schooling will eventually resume.
articles.abstract: Afghanistan’s new government is likely to severely restrict education for girls and women despite the Taliban’s claims that schooling will eventually resume.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — The director of a girls’ school in Kabul desperately wants to learn details of the Taliban’s plan for girls’ education. But she can’t attend the weekly Taliban committee meetings on education. They are for men only.
articles.byline: By Victor J. Blue and David Zucchino
